cluster_relations.rel_desc: The essay aims to explore the impact of urban legends on society.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: impact of urban legends on society

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The essay will discuss why urban legends continue to endure.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a document, text, or discourse primarily concerns or discusses a given topic or subject matter.
args.justification: Both relations link an essay entity to what it will discuss (impact and endurance of urban legends). This is a standard document–topic aboutness relation, so they should share a single canonical predicate representing that the essay is about the given topic.
args.remark: Normalized generic essay–topic relation to `is_about` instead of instance-level wording like 'discusses'.

args.justification: Both edges connect a document-like work (an essay) to the conceptual topics it covers. This fits a document–topic aboutness class that can generalize across essays, articles, books, etc.
The relation expresses a non-causal, non-spatial linkage of content focus (an associative aboutness) between the essay and its topics, best captured under a broad association/semantic-link group.
args.remark: Could also be seen as an ABOUTNESS sub-type of ASSOCIATION in a more fine-grained upper ontology.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a document, text, or discourse primarily concerns or discusses a given topic or subject matter.

executed_decisions.justification: Both edges connect a document-like work (an essay) to the conceptual topics it covers. This fits a document–topic aboutness class that can generalize across essays, articles, books, etc.
The relation expresses a non-causal, non-spatial linkage of content focus (an associative aboutness) between the essay and its topics, best captured under a broad association/semantic-link group.
